text: I'm a big fan of Billy Connolly, as a comedian, a storyteller and just generally as an all round interesting good bloke who is great to listen to. But this book did not do a lot for me, except make me reflect what a great performer he is. The book made me think of scientific reductionism - that tendency of some scientists to break a problem into tiny parts and see the solution in terms of those tiny parts instead of retaining some holistic vision. For Billy Connolly is more than the sum of his parts. If you read these stories without any idea who Billy Connolly was, I suspect you would find them neither terribly interesting nor amusing. In fact, I was surprised how comically thin many of these tall tales and wee stories were. And yet some of them I think I can actually remember him telling and laughing at.I think this comes down to the fact that he is overall a brilliant performer. And to understand this brilliance you need to hear his voice, see his face, sense his energy levels when he was performing, - and so on. The words written down on paper just don't do it for me on their own - but if you add him back into them, they will. There were a few bits which were either slightly amusing or interesting, but slim pickings from a 320 or so pages long book. My advice, give this a miss. He has written other stuff - I'd say go for that.

Over the years I've seen Billy Connolly's numerous stand up routines on TV, but I've always regretted not seeing him live on stage. To make up for this in a small way I treated myself to a signed copy of this brilliantly entertaining book.Connolly has put together his best "tall tales & wee stories" from a lifetime of stand up comedy. There are a few stories here that are new to me, but even the routines I know well still made me laugh out loud. The stories all flow beautifully & so many of them are classics it's impossible to choose any favourites. A great collection of tales from a real legend.

One of the reasons I love Billy Connelly‚Äôs stories is that he tells them just like I do myself - only funny. Unnecessary background, side tracks, lost threads, missed points, picked up threads, another side story, completely unrelated facts about characters in the story, oh and look - there‚Äôs the punchline! I was wondering a little if there could be something in what some reviewers said that these would work less well in written form, but that went out the window at the end of the second sentence and by the end of the second paragraph I was huffing snd puffing and laughing out loud. Can honestly not remember when a book made me do that last time. The missing star is mainly because I felt the book lost pace towards the end and the last few chapters would actually have been better to leave out. Billy (as I expected) also veers a tad close to slapstick and/or toilet humour at times. It‚Äôs a great read though and very strong four stars.

I have been a fan of Billy Connolly for as long as I can remember and sadly never took the opportunity to go and see him live before he retired in 2018. I have seen many of his recorded performances though and I think all of his travelogues as he has been around various parts of the world.This book is a collection of some of his best-known stories that he tells as part of his sets. He is a very human comedian, he is as happy to rip the piss out of himself as he is to call out the hypocrisy of others whilst giving you a stitch laughing about it so much.Some of the tall tales and wee stories in here I have heard before. That doesn‚Äôt make them any less funny though. One of my favourites was his description of swimming in the North Sea as a Child! Provided you don‚Äôt mind a bit (ok a lot) of profanity then there is almost certainly something in here that will make you laugh. Great stuff and thanks for all the laughs, Billy.

I love Billy Connolly having seen him live two or three times and watched all his television programmes including the excellent 'World Tour' series in England, Scotland, Australia and New Zealand. I also have a few of the live DVDs.So I was looking forward to this book. It is a let down. If, like me, you have seen all the above then you will know the majority of the tall tales and wee stories he tells here. There are some I have not heard before though but that does not really make up for it. It is a dip in-and-out book for sure.He says that when you read the book you will hear him and that is so true. Who is this book aimed at? I am not really sure. For Connolly fans it is going over old ground. For someone that does not know him I would say get the 'World Tour' DVDs.

Tall Tales and Wee Stories: The Best of Billy ConnollyBilly Connolly, is one of those comedians who everybody knows and loves, his innate honesty and sharp wit, have had audiences in stitches for five decades. I read this on the bus on the way to and from work and was giggling all the way there and back. The drivers must have thought I'd lost by mind. Highlights include a trip to Births Deaths and Marriages and a chapter on why multiple orgasms have put tremendous pressure on men and women have no idea. This book is typical Billy and I loved every word of it.

Good fun running through transcripts of a lot of the better routines (and some that don't translate very well, falling flat on the page, the absence of the performer of a text never so keenly felt). The ultimate realisation is that Connolly was an even better stage presence than imagined to have elevated some of this way beyond its merit. Ultimately, great spending time with that voice again.

What makes the inhabitants of Glasgow so eternally fascinating! Here, Billy Connolly gives insight through his tenement childhood through his life, told in short vignettes, some laugh-out-loud hilarious. In fact, his secret to enjoying life without fail is to be sure not to lose your ability to laugh. At times curmudgeonly, at times kind, often very raw and profane, but always honest, and with that wee twinkle. Full disclosure - I never had the pleasure of seeing Sir Connolly's standup in person. In fact, I first became aware of him through his portrayal in the film Mrs. Brown, and didn't realize acting was only one of his skills, and not the one he was best known for.

Ach, sorry Billy. This book just isn't that funny. Perhaps my expectations were too high.Connelly starts this book by conceding that he is no longer well enough to stand in front of an audience for over two hours. He is very open about living with Parkinson's Disease but he is also now 78 years old.He was always a very physical comedian; his act was slapstick in many ways with a lot of the humour arising from his gestures and facial expressions. It doesn't translate on to the page especially well. It is indeed a book of 'wee stories' - an there's a gey lot o' them. This is something to dip into from time to time for a wee smile rather than to read in one go.

CYNICAL, HALF-HEARTED RECYCLED CASH IN!Imagine one of your favourite bands or singers who had been recording music for around half a century, decided to put those songs in book form without any hint of the music at all. You would rightly be confused by the move. Beyond the cash generating aspect, what would be the point?...Well that is basically what Connolly has done here.The main problem with this book is that almost all of it has appeared in at least one, sometimes two previous books and a lot of his stand up. It really feels a bit cheeky and lazy when we are getting the exact same stories dragged out for two books in a row?...Surely the readership deserves some quality control?...instead of recycling the same old stories again and again.Of course this has its funny moments now and then, but the truth is that too many of these stories do not translate well onto the page at all. I‚Äôve heard many of them on his stand up stuff and it is delivered a lot better, so much of it is lost when committed to the page, all the drama, nuance and volume stripped away it can feel incredibly dull and disappointing. On the positive side, this is a quick read and it‚Äôs an easy read, but overall there is a good reason why Connolly has not published too many books in his half century involved in the creative and performing arts. Some of these are really awful and not only fall flat but fail miserably and really don‚Äôt do the great man justice at all.

All my favourite stories in written form. Billy Connolly has such a special place in my heart and I always get really emotional talking about him but this one made me laugh rather than cry. I had tears running down my face reading my favourite skits I was laughing that much. It took me five minutes to read one bloody paragraph about the knitted balaclava because I was hysterically laughing. They are just as funny in written form as they are on stage. Love you big yin!

I saw Billy on stage a few years ago and I laughed until it hurt. I think seeing him live definitely helped while reading the book, as I could imagine him strutting round the stage telling his tall tales and wee stories. He's written the book exactly the way he talks, swear words and all.
I t had me laughing out loud! Thank you Billy.

I‚Äôve been a massive Billy Connolly fan for many years. I‚Äôve got lots of DVDs featuring his standup and travelogues, and I was lucky enough to see him live twice. He never fails to make me laugh, even just on a chat show. So it was with great sadness I heard about his retirement, although entirely understandable in his circumstances.I was looking forward to reading this book in which he has gathered many of his most famous stories for posterity. Billy never really told ‚Äòjokes,‚Äô they were always funny anecdotes and tales, often poking fun at himself or other absurdities he saw in every day life. He often talked about sex and bodily functions, and was very sweary and he makes no apology for that, so the book would not be for anyone who did not like this in his live shows because Billy is exactly the same in the book as when performing. If you did love his humour though, you will find many of your favourite stories within these pages.The book is split in to chapters on different, loosely connected topics, but otherwise it is fairly randomly organised with just little anecdotes and longer ones interspersed with comments, thoughts and musings on his life and career. Some people won‚Äôt like it because it isn‚Äôt a particular linear format, but then Billy‚Äôs comedy was never like that. He would start on a topic and then wander off at a tangent when other things occurred to him before looping back round to the original story (or sometimes not!), so the book is a good reflection of his style and really brought him to life for me.I could hear his voice telling these familiar, and some unfamiliar, stories very clearly. Parts of it made me laugh out loud and I had to keep stopping to read bits aloud to The Irishman who kept asking me what I was laughing at. It was a book that really cheered me up during this lockdown. However, it is not the same as watching Billy perform, and you realise how much his expressions and gestures and movements added to the comedy of his story-telling. The ‚ÄòWildebeest‚Äô example illustrates this best. It is many people‚Äôs favourite story of Billy‚Äôs, but it just isn‚Äôt as funny when you can‚Äôt see him doing the vacant expression of the wildebeest and the actions of the lions as they plan their attack.Overall, I really enjoyed reading this but it can‚Äôt replace Billy‚Äôs performances, and I for one will miss him terribly. I wish I could have met him in real life just once before Parkinson‚Äôs started to take effect. I‚Äôm sure it would have been great craic.

The whole opening of the book leads you to believe that these are the stories that Billy really wanted to share and how important writing this book was.Its actually just a transcript of a bunch the Billy's comedy, which i feel takes away a lot of the fun of these humorous tales when you have to read misspelled words instead of hearing Billy's strong Scottish accent, or reading the gestures he did instead of seeing them. And not being surrounded by a laughing audience means that when one of these tales doesn't elicit a chuckle, you just sit there in the awkward silence this book invoked into the atmosphere and question where it's worth trying for another. A few chuckles did arise, but they were few and far between, to the point where i decided to just cut my losses and accept that as a young straight sober not Scottish guy, I'm probably not the target audience for this comedy or this book.

Ah Billy Connolly is just such an icon. His comedy is timeless and classic. I have loved watching his stand up over the years on TV and once had tickets to see him live - which I so regret not being able to use. This book is a collection of small stories from his life, some we've heard before, some new. I found myself reading it in my head using his voice and I think this made it so much funnier. Please read this if you are a fan. Even if you aren't, you will probably enjoy it nonetheless.https://thebeautifulbookbreak.com

Now that Billy has retired from stand up comedy, he‚Äôs finally been persuaded to write down some of his more well known stories. I was reading this and I had his voice in my head, and I was having to stifle laughter when reading this not to wake anyone up. Very funny stories and a great read.

Found myself peeing myself laughing at this one. I love Billy Connolly and this was just the ticket for a lockdown read to dip in and out of. I could visualise him delivering the lines and could hear his voice. I defy you not to grin like an idiot when reading this. LOVED IT!

So, if you're likely to be offended by the swearing, you may as well fuck off now.This is pure Billy. But it's one-dimensional.If watching Billy is like eating a delicious 3-course meal, then reading this book is like looking at the menu.
‚Äú‚Ä¶and laugh. Always look to laugh. Nothing else will ever keep you going like laughter.‚ÄùNo surprise but I laughed out loud the whole way through.

I love Billy Connolly! Always have, always will. First came to know of him whilst growing up outside Glasgow and my mum not allowing me to watch him on TV or listen to him on radio. And of course, being forbidden made me secretly seek him out. My first time seeing him on stage was in Bournemouth in the early 80s and some of the audience walking out!! He actually addressed me a couple of times cos he told some jokes that Glaswegians (or near enough) would REALLY get, so I was in hysterics and pretty obvious.Last time was in 2016 on his High Horse tour where the effects of Parkinson's was obvious, mostly because he pointed them out and made jokes about them! So having this book is great if you're a fan of the man and his legendary comedy. I've also watched him on TV interviews, his Audience With shows, listened to radio interviews, watched his movies (he's also a terrific actor) so many of the stories/anecdotes, I've heard before. Some remembered more than others and some I'd forgotten, but the way he writes them, you can visualise him performing it and hear his voice saying it, and they were just as funny as the first time I'd heard them .... and some even moreso. He really is a fabulous raconteur and, as he says himself, he's not really a joke teller as such, just shares his brilliant observations of and opinions on life, love, sex, rules, "beige", acting, his childhood and much, much more. It's been a while since any book made me laugh out loud (even whilst in bed reading at stupid o'clock in the morning when I didn't want to put it down)!A really easy, hilarious read. I'd give it a 4.5 out of 5.

I grew up listening to Billy, I remember hearing the jobby weecher and the Crucifixion on records my elder brother would play while I was still in short trousers. He's been a part of my life for that long, and now he's retiring from the stage. But it's not all bad news, for he leaves us this, a collection of all his best stories, but written down. Given how much I've heard from him, anything I read, I hear in his voice, which when you include the sex noises is a little weird. He's the finest comedian Scotland has ever produced, this shows why.

I have had this book on the ‚Äúto read‚Äù list for awhile now but it was the announcement that Billy Connolly will be streaming his ‚Äúfarewell‚Äù soon on TV which made me pick it up and I am ever so glad I did. A hilarious collection of Connolly‚Äôs stand up performances which are able to be enjoyed in written form without loosing any of their power.As a fan I was able to easily imagine him telling these stories as only he can, prancing and jumping around and found myself laughing out loud on more than a few occasions.

Bloody Brilliant. I was so lucky to have seen Billy perform live. It‚Äôs so sad that he‚Äôs given up live shows but this book captures some of my favourite stories and it‚Äôs a book I know I will read again and again and continue to laugh out loud!!!!
Always liked Billy Connolly but his humour, for me, is better live. The book covers a lot of stories that people, who like Billy Connolly, will already be familiar with.

There is no plot to this book, but that‚Äôs okay. Connolly is one of the funniest people I know of, and his style of funny is not jokes or terse anecdotes; he starts talking about one subject, veers off in a Grandpa Simpson way (except the detour actually has a point), goes back to the main thread, veers again, finally gets to the end, in the process saying ‚Äúf***‚Äù about 500 times and bringing sex into the story at least once. By the time I get to the end of the story, I‚Äôm lying on my side, tears running down, gasping and wheezing and trying not to wake my husband, because I stayed up a good deal of the night reading, unable to quit. So, yeah, I liked the book. I wish I could have seen Connolly perform live, but at least I‚Äôve seen him on TV enough that, as I read the book, I heard it being told in his voice.

When I did my PhD in West Yorkshire, I discovered Billy Connolly and I bought some tapes of shows of his, which made loads of trips very enjoyable indeed. And so, my husband surprised me with this book last week, and I just needed to read it immediately! Because of the tapes I even imagined the text as read by BC himself ;-) A lot of the stories I already knew, but most of them are just brilliant and I keep on laughing, even if I hear/read them for the 50th time. But there¬¥s also some lesson to be learned, and I quote "Acting your age is about as sensible as acting your street number. You can volunteer to take life seriously, but it¬¥s going to get you anyway. it¬¥s going to win against you in the end. It¬¥s harsh, and you an either break down and complain about how miserable your life is, or you can have a go at it and survive. ... And laugh. Always look to laugh. Nothing else will ever keep you going like laughter." AMEN

A half autobiography, a half story book!This is a book full of what I can only presume is Billy‚Äôs content when he used to be up on stage making people laugh out loud, which the book makes you do as well.You get glimpses of his life through stories and funny moments made all the more real by the Scottish words heavily sprinkled throughout. All in all and I credibly enjoyable story book - lots of swearing though so perhaps if that‚Äôs not what you enjoy it may not be as enjoyable for you. As a Scottish gal myself it doesn‚Äôt bother me in the slightest.The only thing I really didn‚Äôt like was that anytime he was talking about a noise, he spelt it out in full: eg ahhhhhhhhhhhhhh and honestly I HATE this üòÇ I never hear a noise just see lots of letters, but that‚Äôs personal to me so probably won‚Äôt be an issue for anyone else!

Every time I didn't think this worked at all I was suddenly cracking up at a familiar routine and hearing his voice - of course. The Big Yin. A gem. So many gems here. But still, it's not like seeing him live, nor reading his thoughts not meant for a stage, nor even watching a DVD or stream of his best live content. But it's a nice thing to have and hold dear as his life moves on its later stages. He's a legend and there's some great stuff here. That said, sometimes you cringe at the context-less or dated set-ups for rather flat punchlines too; the burden of 'reading' material that was shaggy-dog even if crafted, the burden of having an oral tradition tapped out on a computer for some sort of extra posterity.

I'm a great fan of Billy Connolly the comedian, a lot of the stories in this selection, he has told on stage. Now he has retired from stand up as he has Parkinson's Disease, he is also in his late seventies. What works on stage doesn't work as well on the printed page. Live you would be hard pressed to find a funnier comedian, but it is not just the material; it is his unique delivery, the reaction to the audience and his reaction to their reaction which makes it hilarious. We are social animals, at a comedy club, we often laugh because those around us are laughing but when reading alone we rarely laugh out loud. Billy Connolly has an absurd take on life, which is amusing but works so much better on stage.

I wasn't going to read this but I got it as a gift. The thing is if you're a huge Billy Connolly fan (and I am) then the book is a bit pointless. You've already internalised the contents. The book comprises of transcriptions of his act over the years. I've been watching his DVDs since I was 14, so I skipped over most of the pages due to already knowing what was written in them.Having said that, there was still some stuff that was new to me, I still laughed a good bit, and the final chapters are rather touching. I'm still glad that I read it and I definitely don't begrudge Billy for the book.

It is a lovely book which I will treasure not just for all the stories, most of which I have heard several times but also about his whole approach to this book; he states that you can read it in his voice and I did, every word plus it's the twinkle he has in his eyes when he relates them, I could see that twinkle with every tale. I have loved Billy since the first time I saw him many years ago on a black and white telly - yes, that long ago on Michael Parkinson's show.

A few good chuckles here and there. Started off good, middle was pretty bland and boring. But the end jokes were pretty damn good. I was going to rate it 2 stars but the last 100 pages were great. All of it was just just the same material from his live stand ups, so some of it wasn‚Äôt as good for me because I‚Äôve already heard em a hundred times, but all in all, this book gave me a good chuckle. Wasn‚Äôt as good as I had hoped, but turned out to be okay in the end.

This collection of anecdotes and set pieces from the decades of Billy Connolly's stand up musings should be read carefully on the understanding that there will come at least one wee story which sneaks up on you and causes the laughter to explode out of your nostrils at the least appropriate time.Best read on a bus or train while surrounded by unaware commuters.

HilariousFunny from start to finish. Because l have seen a lot of his shows, I know about 70% of the stories in this book. It's the fourth book, either featuring Billy Connolly or written by him that I have read. Anyone who liked a good laugh and can see the world through his eyes will not be disappointed. If you are easily offended this may not be the book for you. Like many great comedians he gives it straight. People sometimes don't like that. Otherwise it's a great read.

Very much a retelling of his funniest monologues, in print format. Now there were observations that I hadn't seen/heard before which did make me laugh out loud but this is probably best for those not familiar with the big yin. Not for the easily offended which I am not. Particularly enjoyed the dwarf story which was a new one to me.

Just a short note... when reading this book, and I did read it in one day, you will hear Billy‚Äôs voice constantly (at least if you ever watched one of his live shows)I love his stories, I love his style! I love this book!

A pleasure to read and 'hear' his voice in all the stories, familiar and new. For an ex-Glaswegian (if you can ever be) it was partly a road trip in memories and partly just an interesting perspective as always from Billy.

Loved Billy‚Äôs Wee Stories at first, then got a little bored towards the end of the book. Not sure why? But I obviously finished the book. Don‚Äôt like to not complete a book. On the whole, glad I read it for Billy.

I have always loved Billy Connolly. However, I don‚Äôt think most of this material reads well. For it to be really funny requires his brilliant delivery and physical presence. It just (mostly) made me want to watch his old shows. Strong ending though.

Don‚Äôt read in public! I absolutely loved this book. I laughed my way through it. At times I had to put it down I was unable to continue reading for laughing! Definitely one to dip into if you need cheering up.
I love Billy, so this was great for me. A collection of short stories, just like he is on stage :)
Great but you had to see him live
Really enjoyed this with some laugh out loud tales
4.5. A treasure, full of my favorite stand-up routines Billy Connolly has ever done.
Excellent read. It's mostly his stand up stuff but who cares? Brings back memories of seeing him live and all you have to do is imagine it's Billy himself reading it to you.
I absolutely loved this book. Just lots of wee stories and what‚Äôs more I read the whole thing in Billy‚Äôs accent. Great story teller and all round legend

It was alright. I mainly read it because of a negative review on Amazon. Someone was appalled by the language and, yes, there is swearing in it but nothing too over the top. The style did wear after a while.

And now for something completely different for me to read! At the outset, Billy Connolly states that ‚Äòhe writes like he talks‚Äô and he really does. This book is laugh-out-loud funny; deep aching belly laughs. His comedy translates well to the written format. Connolly is a master of mixing unrelated topics and infers great humour from mundane life activities. I did not realise that his performances are totally unscripted (he only takes a short list of topics on stage) and he leverages his ‚Äòlist‚Äô to see what direction his stories can go in, generating variety within his story telling. He follows where his brain takes him; a kind of stream of consciousness or improvisation approach. Overall a great read and a deep insight into a great mind.

Can't go wrong with this one. Started it last night and was shaking with laughter (in bed) within a page - really. I think I was annoying the Wife with my shaking cos she's trying to read history, but I couldn't help it, every second sentence paints a funny image. Impossible to read with anything other than Billy's voice in your head, which just makes it more entertaining. This guy will be such a sad loss when he goes.Finished it now, and the strange thing is that if you force yourself NOT to hear Billy's voice as you're reading, then it isn't all that funny! It's his personality that makes these stories hilarious (or even poignant). The very last pages are the ones you'll remember the most: laugh as often as you can and don't worry about embarrassing yourself because "you're a long time looking at the lid". Aye!
A collection of Billy's finest anecdotes: beautifully compiled but sadly the magic of his delivery isn't there. My head says 3 stars and my heart says 5. Today my heart wins.

A good read. More of a written collection of the stories from his comedy gigs over the years. They are entertaining but it emphasises the point that it takes a good comedian to deliver a story to make them even funnier.
A great book indeed. I love that you can go to any page at all, & find a great story. I've never laughed like that at a book before.
Very funny. Laughing to the last pages!!
Made me grin and giggle and at some points so funny my eyes would water and yes, get funny looks off people!
Funny as ever. All The big yin's best stuff. I laughed at every page!

I just loved this! I laughed so much whilst sitting in the waiting room for a hospital appointment that I had to put the book away as I was worried that they would wheel me off and keep me. You can really hear Billy talking to you just like during one of his shows and it leaves you with a big smile on your face. What's not to love!

I don't like giving this book just one star as it's nicely produced and well edited, but it's actually a bit of a cheat.What I mean by this is that all it is a collection of Billy's stand-up routines, all of which are hilarious when he delivers them on stage but they fall flat on the page. There are a few great stories but most of them are anything but; the fact that I knew most of them wasn't the problem as I can listen to him on YouTube indefinitely (in fact, I would take an audio recordings of his comedy onto my desert island).If only the publisher's had had the courage to be honest it could have made for a much better book; they could have had a preface by the editor who transcribed the material with a related commentary; or, if Billy actually did this mundane task himself, surely he'd say something about it in the intro. I've transcribed audio material before and it's really hard work, as is the editing that has to then follow.There's no clue on the cover or front matter about who did the dirty work but in the acknowledgements the first name to get a thank you (and his own sentence) is Nick Davies. Who is Nick Davies? I will ask Google right now ... it turns out he's a bigshot editor who's worked for some of the main London publishing houses. I assume he's too high and mighty to have done this transcribing task himself (maybe Billy actually did it?. Maybe one of his household minions?) What I do know is that publishers will sell their own mother to get their hands on a book by a celebrity of Billy's stature, as it's like making a sequel of a popular film -- there's a ready-made audience ready to buy it however indifferent its quality may be.This is what Nick Davies said in The Bookseller's puff piece about the book:‚ÄúAs his many millions of fans will know, Billy‚Äôs stories can be rude, warm-hearted, anarchic, joyful, angry, far-fetched, down-to-earth and everything in between. They are also beautifully constructed, brilliantly paced and deeply funny. I‚Äôve written to Billy at various points over the last 15 years to ask if he would bring these stories to the printed page and I‚Äôm thrilled that he has finally agreed. Tall Tales is an absolute treat of a book that will delight readers everywhere.‚ÄùIn conclusion, it's important to get Billy's jokes in book form -- particularly for people like me of a Scottish persuasion. But I would have appreciated a description of how the book came together and who was the poor sod who did the actual work.

3.5This was jolly good fun. It's got a lot of hilarious stories from Billy, classic bits from his stand-up, amazing folk tales and jokes. The thing is, Billy is a riot when telling these tales and they really come to life when he's enacting them, so by only reading them you don't get as much from them. Nevertheless, they're written in his style so you can almost hear him when reading. Great book for any Big Yin fan.

There was many occasions while reading this book where the dog looked at me strangely as I was laughing out loud so much I occassionally snorted. If you love Billy Connelly you'll love this book, there are some stories you'll recognise (scratchy wool and balaclava) and lots of new ones. ü§£ü§£ü§£
I laughed out loud (not the kindle edition but a real book).

More stars required - without doubt the funniest book I‚Äôve ever read and I know already that I will re-read it. What an absolute legend. Laughed out loud throughout this book, laughing thinking back and I know I‚Äôll continue to laugh. Mission accomplished Outstandingly good. Everyone should read this - in case you can‚Äôt tell I LOVED this book
Brilliant !Funniest book I've read in ages. Although probably helps if you can "ken a wee bittae Scottish".

This was fun with many of Connolly's classics (Christmas Dinner, Dwarf on the Bus, etc.). I found it to be a slow read, though, as it was necessary to hear his voice in my head as I read. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone without any familiarity with his stand-up comedy, though. It also helped to read with a smart phone at the ready to look up all of the unfamiliar Scottish slang.
A very light and amusing read featuring all his classic stories. Not quite the same as watching him tell them in the hilarious way that he does but still great fun.

I've always liked watching Billy Connolly's stand up. He doesn't tell jokes as such. His humour is primarily observational with the addition of his own style of speaking and the language of the Clyde shipyards. On stage over the years that worked. In my opinion this does not transfer to the written form. This book is just a collection of the stories he has told over the years interspersed with some rants about modern life. These rants made him sound like Jeremy Clarkson, a comparison which I am sure Connolly would hate. Largely read this during a period of covid-related self-isolation, when the short "chapters" was all I could concentrate on and the humour was a necessary tonic. Indeed some of the stories were laugh out loud funny... causing physical pain to my ribs which were already sore from coughing... Others were probably as funny, but I had either heard them before on old recordings of his gigs (on LPs - yes I am that old) and his TV appearances, or read them in his earlier "Unauthorised Biography". His material was never politically correct, even in the days before such a thing was unheard of... he always navigated the line of what was "acceptable/shocking" frequently crossing it... But there was never any overt sense of malice in his earlier material... even the cack-handed "Last Supper/Crucifixion" story that doesn't come across well on paper, without his distinctive delivery. He was never a "political" comedian... he usually found humour in the ridiculous, and especially the ridiculous that we accept as normal. However, some of his later material, perhaps in the light of the PC/woke climate and the reaction against that by some, comes across as lazily reactionary. He sees the PC/woke agenda as "beige" but instead of taking on substantial examples of this he focusses on reversing beepers on bin-lorries and ambulance being printed back to front on the front of said vehicles. Sadly this merely comes across as him as a relic of a former age raging at a world he doesn't feel part of any more... which is frustrating given that I too am a relic of that former age in which he was a giant. Indeed THE Big Yin.

For those familiar with Billy Connolly and his way of telling his stories, complete with arm waving and wandering about on stage, this book revisits a great many of those stories. The stories frequently ramble with many asides and digressions, as well as sound effects that the readers have to put in for themselves, but they are a true reflection of his stage performances, and for those who have seen those performances, the imagination will kick in and you can envisage him gesticulating and generally enjoying himself with his audience. Many of the stories involve rants that become increasingly amusing, and every story ends with some sort of punch line, but, as Billy himself says, he dose not actually tell jokes, he makes his stories amusing.For those not familiar with Billy Connolly, a word of warning. Billy believes that Keith Tynan did the English language, and television, a great service by being the first person to ever use the F word on television. According to Billy this was a liberating event, so much so, that he enjoys using that word quite liberally in both his stage appearances and this book. If you are easily offended, then this book is not for you. If you believe yourself to be broadminded, then you may well enjoy the ramblings of a truly amusing, and well informed, Glaswegian.

In December 2018 after years of dominating stages around the world for decades Billy Connolly announced that he was retiring from that part of his repertoire. Equally if you've had the pleasure of catching him live you might recognise some of these wee tales.
